Fresh water is a precious resource that is essential to human health, food and energy security, poverty eradication and many other aspects of sustainable development. Water-related ecosystems have always provided natural sites for human settlements, along with a wealth of ecosystem services. Yet, like other natural resources, water is under threat. The demand for water has outpaced population growth, and half the worldâ€™s population is already experiencing severe water scarcity at least one month a year. Most rivers in Africa, Asia and Latin America are more polluted now than they were in the 1990s. An estimated 50 to 70 per cent of the worldâ€™s natural wetland area has been lost over the last 100 years. While substantial progress has been made in increasing access to clean drinking water and sanitation, billions of peopleâ€”mostly in rural areasâ€”still lack these basic services.

Worldwide Development

The data set contains percentage values of how many people have access to safe and affordable drinking water in different countires, regions and continents. These values are available for the three locations Allarea ğŸ˜, Rural ğŸ” and Urban ğŸ™, while for few geo areas there are only one or two of those.

The following diagram shows the worldwide development between 2000 and 2017.

Continental Differences

The differences between countries, regions and continents are huge. Even inside those geographical areas there are huge differences.
To get an overview over the worldwide situation, the following diagram is reduced to continents or continental areas. The zero-line visualizes the world index of the selected year. In continents above the base line people have better access to drinking water than the average of the world. Continents below the line do have worse conditions than the world average.

This is a project I did in the course Studio Information Aesthetics & Engineering Extended in my Digital Ideation studies at Lucerne University of Applied Science and Arts HSLU.
In the beginning it was important to analyse the dataset to get some interesting findings. Afterwards I was finally able to get to know d3.js and try to visualize my concept.
